New Records: Texas Rangers became the first team to win 11 road games in a single postseason.
Texas Rangers became the first team to win 13 postseason games.
Marcus Semien homered in a four-run ninth, making it the 13th time Texas scored at least three runs in an inning this postseason.
Key Match Events: Corey Seager took a mighty swing and barely connected, sending a squibber through an open area on the left side of the infield for his team’s first hit in the seventh inning.

Mitch Garver broke a scoreless tie with an RBI single in the seventh and the Rangers won the first World Series championship in their 63-season franchise history by beating the Arizona Diamondbacks 5-0 in Game 5.
Marcus Semien homered in a four-run ninth and the Rangers, held hitless for six innings by Zac Gallen, finished a record 11-0 on the road this postseason.
Pre-Game Insights: The Rangers were due for a title after enduring heartache 12 years ago in one of the all-time Fall Classic gut punches.
Post-Match Reflections: Texas Rangers manager Bruce Bochy won his fourth World Series title 13 years to the day after his first, which came in 2010 when the Giants beat the Rangers.
The Rangers became the first team to win a World Series game despite having no hits or runs through six innings.
Texas will celebrate with a parade in the Arlington entertainment district near its stadium on Friday.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The Rangers committed no errors in the World Series, the first team to do so since the 1966 Baltimore Orioles.
Texas became the first team to win 13 postseason games.
The Rangers have been eyeing this moment since Dec. 1, 2021, when they committed more than a half-billion dollars to sign Seager, Semien and pitcher Jon Gray.
Others: The Rangers were led by players like trade-deadline acquisition Jordan Montgomery, replacement closer José Leclerc and backup outfielder Travis Jankowski who picked up the slack throughout for these resilient Rangers.
The Rangers finished off baseball’s third all-wild card World Series by outlasting Arizona in a white-knuckle pitchers’ duel.
The Rangers were the first team to win 11 road games in a single postseason, according to OptaSTATS.
